SP.SPEAKER: Miss SELWYN.
SP.P: I have often wondered, my dear grandmamma, to think how it is possible for you to be so cheerful who are always in pain, and neither can visit or be much visited.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. VERNON.
SP.P: Many circumstances conduce to my cheerfulness. My Creator, as one of his bountiful gifts, has endowed me with an active mind, in consequence of which, I have acquired a habit of constant employment. But above all, the reliance which a long life has taught me to place on my Maker, naturally produces serenity of mind; and I look back with satisfaction on the days that are past, as I trust, guided by his unerring hand, I have not spent them unprofitably. I am sure I have not unthankfully. The blessings I enjoy are manifold. Misfortunes I have sha∣red with the rest of mankind. Grateful and resigned, I wait for the moment of my dissolution.

SP.SPEAKER: Miss SELWYN.
SP.P: I hope, however, that your life will be spared many years longer; for I have a great deal to learn; and though my mamma is all goodness, yet she has not so much time for conversation as you have; besides, it would break my heart to be separated from you.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. VERNON, [smiling.]
SP.P: The heart, my dear, is not so eay broken as you ima∣gine; great and heavy have been my afflictions. My mind was naturally weak, and apt to repine at every dis∣appointment, this my parents early observed, their kind attention to me strengthened it; they soon convinced me, that a dependance on this world is vain, and taught me to draw confolation from that source which never fails. At what time may we expect the travellers? are you not impatient to see your cousin?

SP.SPEAKER: Miss SELWYN.
SP.P:
Indeed I am. Mamma told me at parting that she hoped to be at home by dinner to-day, and I ordered it accordingly. I am afraid my appearance will be very aukward in the company of . Seven years resi∣dence
in France, has no doubt, made her all accomplish∣ed.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. VERNON.
SP.P: I hope it has improved her, or it will be seven years thrown away: but why should you be aukward, because she is accomplished? you have had the advantage of a good education, and under the eye of an amiable mother, whose acquirements and constant attention must have given you a benefit your cousin wanted, separated as she has been for such a length of time from all her relations.

SP.SPEAKER: Miss SELWYN.
SP.P: My aunt holds me so cheap for having been educated in England, though the forbears to speak her sentiments, I think her looks seem to say, when my mamma kindly commends my behaviour, "my daughter will soon con∣vince you whose judgment is the best."

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. VERNON.
SP.P: You should avoid all suspicions of this kind: for it is un∣generous to judge of passes in the minds of others merely for their looks; had your mamma thought as you do, I dare say she would have been equally hurt, but would have forborn to express her chagrin to any one.

SP.SPEAKER: Miss SELWYN.
SP.P: I saw yesterday morning tears start into her eyes, at a remark my aunt made on home education, but it is true, that instead of taking it up, she only turned and embraced me with the greatest affection, and seemed, whilst she pres∣sed me to her bosom, to say, "I am satisfied with you." My aunt was too full of her approaching meeting with Cecilia, to say even adieu to me.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. VERNON.
SP.P:
The neglect was pardonable. I must not have you think of it. Your mamma's conduct through life will be an excellent guide for you. Be thankful to GOD that you have before your eyes such an example. She has sacrificed her own feelings on many occasions; and when I lost my son, consented, for my sake, to take your aunt and cousins into this house. You are old enough to re∣mark, that they are in some respects different from
both in sentiment and character: yet to this she has sub∣mitted, and without once deviating from the respect which she thinks due to the relief of so near a relation.

SP.SPEAKER: Miss SELWYN.
SP.P: I am sure, my cousin George often treats my mamma shamefully, and yet my aunt seldom reproves him for it.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. VERNON.
SP.P: It is with great concern I see his mother's blind indul∣gence towards him; but as he has a good understanding, I hope he will in time learn to behave with propriety.
SP.STAGE: [Enter Master Vernon hastily, he runs to Miss Selwyn, then speaks.]
SP.P: I have broke my kite, cousin; do give me some paper to mend it with?

SP.SPEAKER: Miss SELWYN.
SP.P: I will give you some paper, George, with as much plea∣sure, as seeing you pay duty and respect to your grand∣mamma would give me.

SP.SPEAKER: Master VERNON.
SP.P: I do not mean to be rude to grandmamma, and will kiss her if the pleases; for, indeed, she is never cross to me; but I heard Miss Ward complain the other day, how ill-natured her grandmother was: and she said, she did not know what use old women were of, if they must live, but to sit in the chimney corner and knit stockings.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. VERNON.
SP.P: If you have adopted this sentiment, George, my affec∣tion can be of little estimation in your opinion; yet I feel myself your parent, and am truly anxious for your welfare.

SP.SPEAKER: Miss SELWYN.
SP.P: I think Miss Ward was quite inexcuseable to use such expressions; for if she has no sense of duty, or propriety herself, she should not have endeavoured to pervert the minds of others.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. VERNON.
SP.P: Very true, my love; but young people who are in ha∣bits of insolence, seldom consider to whom they address it, or think of the prevalence of example.
SP.STAGE: [Miss Selwyn furnishes the young gentleman with paper, then speaks.]

SP.SPEAKER: Miss SELWYN.
SP.P: There, cousin, you may now repair the damage your kite has received; and I hope you will allow, that if old woman are useless, young one's are not so?

SP.SPEAKER: Master VERNON.
SP.P: Why, I hope you do not call yourself a woman? how∣ever I thank you for your kindness. As soon as I have mended my kite-and dried, it, I will go and try if it will fly.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. VERNON.
SP.P: I think I heard a carriage stop: if so, our hopes or fears, will soon become certainty.

DIV3.STAGE: [Enter Mrs. Selwyn.]

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. SELWYN.
SP.P: How is my dear mother? I have had ten thousand alarms for your health during my absence.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. VERNON.
SP.P: Your daughter has paid such attention to me, that I have hardly felt your loss: which will, I hope, induce you not to confine yourself so much as formerly. Have you brought home your sister and the young Frenchwoman?

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. SELWYN.
SP.P: I have, madam: they only wait your permission to be admitted.—My beloved Teresa, you are dearer to me than ever, for shewing such sweet attention to your grandmo∣ther.

SP.SPEAKER: Miss SELWYN.
SP.P: I am happy to obtain your approbation so easily, mam∣ma; for in so doing, I have only followed the bent of my own inclinations.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. VERNON.
SP.P: Postpone at present these joyful effusions.—It will be proper for Teresa to welcome her aunt and Cousin; in the mean time. I will, with your assistance, daughter, prepare myself for the approaching interview.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. SELWYN.
SP.P: Go then, my love, into the parlour, and tell my sist∣er, her mother will attend her immediately.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. VERNON.
SP.P: I am all anxiety and apprehension, whilst I enquire whether my son's daughter is worthy of him?

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. SELWYN.
SP.P: Cecilia is certainly not such a character as will please you. Her education may make a figure among the gay and thoughtless, but is no more suited to the pleasures of a fire side, than such pleasures are suited to her.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. VERNON.
SP.P: My fears were then prophetic when I warned her in∣fatuated mother against sending her to a convent. But what is to be expected when a child is removed so many years from the watchful eyes of anxious affection? will you assist me to make the usual alteration in my dress, that I may avoid coming up stairs any more to-day; and then, with a palpitating heart, will I embrace this dear perverted child.

DIV3.HEAD: SCENE, changes to a Parlour.
[Mrs. G. Vernon and her daughter.]

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. G. Vernon.
SP.P: It is strange no one comes to welcome us.

SP.SPEAKER: Miss Vernon.
SP.P: Not at all; I dare say my aunt is decorating and docu∣menting Teresa, that she may not appear aukward before me, [with of her head,] she may try, but I do not fancy she will succeed very well.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. G. VERNON.
SP.P: You are much mistaken, my dear. Your cousin is a very amiable and accomplished girl, nor does she ever want decorating, for her dress is always neat, and such as she may be seen in before any one.

SP.SPEAKER: Miss VERNON.
SP.P:
Well, I allow she may be neat, but she cannot know
how to put her cloaths on as fashionably as I do, for I have been dressed like a woman ever since I went to France.
SP.STAGE: [Enter Miss SELWYN who goes to embrace her cousin with great affection.]
SP.P: Welcome to England, my dear Cecilia; I cannot ex∣press the joy I feel that I once more see you in this house. Pardon me, aunt, for taking notice of my cousin, before I have paid my duty to you; but my joy at seeing her oc∣casioned it.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. G. VERNON [embraces her.]
SP.P: You are forgiven, my love, for a very natural and pleasing omission; I am glad you retain the affection which, even in infancy, you felt for my Cecilia. [To her daughter, who stands gazing at Miss Selwyn in an affect∣ed manner] you neither speak or return your cousin's kind reception—recollect yourself, my dear.

SP.SPEAKER: Miss VERNON.
SP.P: My cousin is so grown and altered, that I should not have known her any where; but I am very happy to fee her again.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. G. VERNON.
SP.P: Your separation, consider has been long enough to make an equal change in both of you. How is my mo∣ther, Teresa? perhaps she may like to see me alone first. I will, therefore, find George, and then attend her in her own apartment. My absence will accelerate your in∣timacy, I hope, for at present, young Ladies, you seem very distant to each other.

SP.SPEAKER: Miss VERNON.
SP.P: Indeed I do not mean to appear cool; but I have been so lost in admiration of you, cousin, that it tied my tongue.

SP.SPEAKER: Miss SELWYN.
SP.P: You are very kind, my dear Cecilia; but I cannot be vain enough to believe what your politeness leads you to say.

SP.SPEAKER: Miss VERNON.
SP.P:
Doubt my veracity, child? "true as the needle to the pole."
But come, tell me ten thousand things at once; I long to know how you amuse yourself?

SP.SPEAKER: Miss SELWYN.
SP.P: I can sooner tell you how I employ myself; for as to amusements except joining your brother George, in his plays sometimes, I have very few; I am, however, seldom unemployed: but now you are returned I may promise myself many pleasures suitable to my time of life, which the want of a companion has for some time deprived me of.

SP.SPEAKER: Miss VERNON.
SP.P: La, coz! you talk as if we were to play like children still; I like nothing in the old style; besides, I have too much vivacity to continue the same employment long, la, la, la, [sings, and dances before the looking-glass.]

SP.SPEAKER: Miss SELWYN.
SP.P: You have charming spirits, and will find me ready to join you in both singing and dancing, for I am very fond of them both.

SP.SPEAKER: Miss. VERNON.
SP.P: O, I adore them! am in extasies at an Opera, and expire at the sight of Vestris.

SP.SPEAKER: Miss SELWYN.
SP.P: 'Tis a pity then you should run the risque of hearing and seeing them. I think it would give me much pleas∣ure to go to such an entertainment; but as to expiring, I am sure I would not venture to go, could I expect the pleasure would be so exquisite as to produce such an ef∣fect upon me.

SP.SPEAKER: Miss VERNON.
SP.P: You are all nonchalance. While I am endowed with Esprit. Esprit! that makes me the life of company.—but a tonjours when alime. Have you no wish to go to that dear place I have just quitted?

SP.SPEAKER: Miss SELWYN.
SP.P: If you mean France, I confess, my desire is strong to go thither: and I have my mamma's promise to take me, when my dear grandmamma no longer requires our at∣tendance on her.

SP.SPEAKER: Miss VERNON.
SP.P: Does the old lady give as much good advice as she used to do? possitively, if she begins with me I shall advise her, knowing her great fondness for experiments, to send for Mousieur Blunchard, and mount in one of his air bal∣looms, and then I will bribe him, never to let her come back again.

SP.SPEAKER: Miss SELWYN.
SP.P: Fie! Cecilia, It is shocking to hear you talk so of any old woman, but of such a grandmother, unpardonable.

SP.SPEAKER: Miss VERNON.
SP.P: You must expect this, and a great deal more; for I al∣ways speak what comes uppermost. It is a la mode de France.

SP.SPEAKER: Miss SELWYN.
SP.P: La mode de France is not a very pleasant mode, if it inculcates a want of feeling and respect to our nearest and dearest relations. You have not enquired after your bro∣ther; yet he was a sweet little fellow when you parted from him.

SP.SPEAKER: Miss VERNON.
SP.P: I have quite forgot what he was. But I know it would be better for me if I had no brother; for then I should have a larger fortune.

SP.SPEAKER: Miss SELWYN.
SP.P: How can you talk so? what wish your brother dead!

SP.SPEAKER: Miss VERNON.
SP.P: It is no proof because I wish myself to have a better fortune that I desire my brother's death. Suppose he was your brother, would not that do as well?

SP.SPEAKER: Miss SELWYN.
SP.P: Well! I have no idea of indulging a wish for any thing to be different from what Providence has ordered it. I have often, to be sure, wished I had a sister; but then the thought has been forgotten as soon as I obtained a companion.

SP.SPEAKER: Miss VERNON.
SP.P:
But consider with what old fashioned notions you have
been educated; never to think or speak but by rule, whilst Frolic has been my Mother, Whim my Sister, and their dear attendant Nonsense, constantly hovering about me. Your masters are fusty old Englishmen, chosen by your grandmamma, because they are mighty civil well behaved men. If you perform well, they are too phlegmatic to praise you; if ill, the never forget it. My instruc∣tors were Petit Maitres, dressed dernier gout, with a chapeau de bras. Whilst I was playing, or dancing, they were all extasies; charmante! adorable! tres bien! bon! encore! were repeated till I was even almost tired of hearing my own praises. Vive la hagatelle, shall be my motto, whilst youth, (a Frenchman would say) and beauty remain.

SP.SPEAKER: Miss SELWYN.
SP.P: I am sure, my dear parents have always encouraged my liveliness, and at times I have very great spirits; it is true, they wished me to distinguish between real cheer∣fulness and levily. The latter of which, I own, is al∣ready so disagreeable in my eyes, that I am sorry to see any young lady encourage it.

SP.SPEAKER: Miss VERNON.
SP.P: That is as much as to say, you do not like me. N'im∣porte. The opinion of a girl bred in obscurity, will ne∣ver distress me. But your behaviour need not have been quite so English at our first meeting.

SP.SPEAKER: Miss SELWYN.
SP.P: I am sorry, cousin, you found any thing in my speech to apply to yourself. You talked of the opera and Vestris as having seen them; how was that possible in a Con∣vent?

SP.SPEAKER: Miss VERNON.
SP.P:
By the mean of a little art and good friends, my dear. I accompanied the mother of one of our boarders to Pa∣ris, persuaded the Lady Abbess, though almost as old and grumpy as my grandmamma, that she would oend mamma, if she refused my accepting the invitation of so great a lady as Madame la Come de Resselle; under
this idea, she consented, and for one fortnight I enjoyed all the pleasures of the beau monde.

SP.SPEAKER: Miss SELWYN.
SP.P: How could you receive pleasure from any diversion obtained by the meanness of deceit? I should have hoped, my Cecilia, had had more pride than to descend to it, Seven years ago you would blushed at only being supposed capable of such an action.

SP.SPEAKER: Miss VERNON.
SP.P: You who have never gone beyond the pales of the vil∣lage church-yard, nor heard precepts but from the old fashioned months of your relations, have no idea what young people will submit to when pleasure is in view; for my part, I think there is no harm in an innocent deception; and often laugh at the figure I made when I went into the Convent, a little formal demure Miss grandmamma's best girl: said my prayers might and morning; preferred reading good books to the old lady, to a game of romps: and would not have told a mensonge for the world.

SP.SPEAKER: Miss SELWYN.
SP.P: I am sorry to say any thing harsh to you, dear cousin, particularly in these first moments of our meeting; but indeed, if you continue to use such expressions, I must only keep you company when you are restrained by the presence of those relations whom you hold so cheap. What you have just said, must, however, be all mere l∣lery; when you are serious, I shall hear very different sen∣timents, from you.

SP.SPEAKER: Miss VERNON.
SP.P: Though I do not thank you much for the former part of your speech, yet I cannot help telling you, that my sentiments never differ, for I disclaim every thing like seriousness; the age of sixteen was never made for that: it is the prime of pleasure, gaiety and dress. Apropos, I long to shew you the sweet elegant becoming ornaments I have brought home, if the Barbares at the Custom-house keep their odious hands from them.

SP.SPEAKER: Miss SELWYN.
SP.P: I shall be much delighted with a sight of them, as the French are generally allowed to have great taste and ele∣gance in dress.

SP.SPEAKER: Miss VERNON.
SP.P: And when placed with judgment I say no more. Vou me compren?

DIV3.STAGE: [Enter Master Vernon who runs and kisses his sister.]

SP.SPEAKER: Miss VERNON.
SP.P: How impoli, George! you should only touch my cheek.

SP.SPEAKER: Master VERNON.
SP.P: I am not a Frenchman, sister; nor do I desire to be one, that is more. Why, I never saw any body ut such a queer figure in my life as you do, all frizzled and pow∣dered. I like my cousin a great deal better.

SP.SPEAKER: Miss VERNON.
SP.P: With all my heart; your good opinion would only make me dislike myself. I wish dinner was ready, [takes out a dirty looking knife.] I long to exercise you, [ad∣dressing it] for I am very hungry.

SP.SPEAKER: Master VERNON.
SP.P: And do you think grandmamma will suffer such a nasty looking knife as that to be used at the table she sits at? why, it would quick shock her.

SP.SPEAKER: Miss VERNON.
SP.P: It is what I have used constantly these three years, and shall continue to cut with it in spite of all she can say to the contrary; I am not quite vulgar enough to eat with one, as I suppose you all do.

SP.SPEAKER: Master VERNON.
SP.P: There you are mistaken, Mrs. Frenchwoman; I often wish my aunt's eyes behind her, because she watches me so narrowly, for fear I should put any thing to my mouth with my knife; but then we are not absurd or dirty enough to use such a nasty thing as that.

SP.SPEAKER: Miss VERNON.
SP.P: I wish you would hold your ridiculous tongue, and not talk of things you cannot understand. Go to school, that is the properest place for you.

SP.SPEAKER: Master VERNON.
SP.P: Hold your tongue—who sent for you to give an opin∣ion? I shall not submit to you, indeed.

SP.SPEAKER: Miss SELWYN.
SP.P: Pray restrain yourselves, my dear cousins, I am ex∣tremely shocked to see such near relations quarrelling, and particularly, so soon ater such a long separation.

SP.SPEAKER: Miss VERNON.
SP.P: What right has he to laugh at me? I will use my knife if I like it.

SP.SPEAKER: Master VERNON.
SP.P: And what right had you to call me impoli, or in plain English, Brute?

SP.SPEAKER: Miss SELWYN.
SP.P: I beg you will compose yourselves. How much would your conduct distress all our parents, if they knew it?

SP.SPEAKER: Miss VERNON.
SP.P: Tell them of it with all my heart; perhaps you will recommend yourself by it.

SP.SPEAKER: Miss SELWYN.
SP.P: No one but you, cousin, would have supposed me ca∣pable of designed ill-nature. But you do not know what I am, and have forgot what I was.

SP.SPEAKER: Miss VERNON.
SP.P: You can praise yourself, however, that I can perceive. A fine chance for happiness have I, to be documented by a conceited cousin, and a boorish brother. But I will never let mamma rest till she removes me from this hateful house.

SP.SPEAKER: Miss SELWYN.
SP.P: You distress me greatly, Cecilia, by thus misconstruing my intentions, [takes her hand with great affection.] I am sure proving myself sincerely your friend will afford hap∣piness to myself; and I hope, this house, once so dear to you, and which you regretted leaving when your mam∣ma sent you abroad, will be highly estimated as ever.

SP.SPEAKER: Miss VERNON.
SP.P: That is a vain hope: when I liked this dull situation, I did not know better; but now I must detest every thing like retirement. That one fortnight at Paris, has spoi me for any thing but living in the world.

SP.SPEAKER: Miss SELWYN.
SP.P: So far from making me impatient to see the world, you render me afraid of entering it. What dreadful effects, to make one hate home, and the peace and quietness to be found there only! you cannot always be amused from morning till night.

SP.SPEAKER: Miss VERNON.
SP.P: I am sure we were so at Paris, and wanted still more hours for amusement; but then to be sure, I was fadly fatigued, and did not recover it for many days after I re∣turned to the Convent, but that was only for want of use.

SP.SPEAKER: Master VERNON.
SP.P: Well, sister, I wish you would talk of something else besides your outlandish manner of passing your time, it would do you more good to go and play at trap-bli with me.

SP.SPEAKER: Miss VERNON.
SP.P: Keep your sentiments to yourself, sir; they are by no mean desirable in my opinion. What is the old lady dressing herself all this time? she does not shew much impatience to see me; but, perhaps, she is beautifying, ha! ha! [Laughs.]

SP.SPEAKER: Miss SELWYN.
SP.P: I will enquire what is the matter; for my dear grand∣mamma's great age makes me constantly apprehensive about her. [She rings the bell.]

SP.SPEAKER: Miss VERNON.
SP.P: You need not hurry her, Teresa, for I find no difficulty to smother my impatience.

SP.SPEAKER: Miss SELWYN.
SP.P: I am sorry for it. [Enter a footman.] Have you heard any thing of my grandmamma, John?

SP.SPEAKER: JOHN.
SP.P: She is now upon the stairs, miss, I believe she has been kept above by some complaint, because her maid went for drops.

SP.SPEAKER: Miss SELWYN. [agitated.]
SP.P: You alarm me greatly; but I will go and see her my∣self. [As she is quitting the room, enter Sally.]

SP.SPEAKER: SALLY.
SP.P: My lady is gone into the dining parlour with your mammas, ladies, and desires your company there.

SP.SPEAKER: Miss SELWYN.
SP.P: How is my grandmamma, Sally? I hope not very ill?

SP.SPEAKER: SALLY.
SP.P: No, miss, only a little faint. But you are so soon frightened.

SP.SPEAKER: Miss VERNON.
SP.P: Frightened, indeed! I never heard such a fuss about an old woman in my life; it is quite absurd.

SP.SPEAKER: SALLY.
SP.P: O, Miss Cecilia, I am glad you are come home, the house will seem alive now.

SP.SPEAKER: Miss VERNON.
SP.P: That it will, if my endeavours can make it so.
SP.STAGE: [Sally is going to speak, but is interrupted by

SP.SPEAKER: Miss SELWYN.
SP.P: You need not stay here, Sally, we shall go to the din∣ing parlour immediately. [Sally goes out.] How can you cousin encourage that impertinent girl to prate? it is a liberty she never dared to take with me.

SP.SPEAKER: Miss VERNON.
SP.P: Keep your advice for those who will attend to it, I shall never be a listner. Come, let us go, that I may be made a show of.

DIV3.HEAD: SCENE, the Dining Parlour.
DIV3.STAGE: [Mrs. Vernon, Mrs. G. Vernon, Miss and Master Ver∣non, Mrs. and Miss Selwyn, sitting round the table af∣ter dinner, eating fruit, &c.]

SP.SPEAKER: Master VERNON.
SP.P: I KNEW very well, sister, that you would not dare to pull out that nasty quee knife, before grandmamma, notwithstanding what you said.

SP.SPEAKER: Miss VERNON.
SP.P: I think, sir, I had enough of your imperence before dinner; I must claim my mamma's protection from any more of it.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. G. VERNON.
SP.P: It is a shame, George, that you should quarrel with your sister so soon after your meeting.

SP.SPEAKER: Master VERNON.
SP.P: O, you need not take her part; she wants no second, I assure you, mamma, she was quite a match for my cou∣sin and me together before dinner.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. VERNON.
SP.P: I am sorry, Teresa, to hear that you have been dispu∣ting, and wonder from whose example you could learn it?

SP.SPEAKER: Miss SELWYN.
SP.P: Indeed, my dear grandmamma, I have not deserved your censure on this occasion; George quite mistakes.

SP.SPEAKER: Miss VERNON.
SP.P:
There is no occasion to tell tales. Though, to speak
truth, we had a fine battle of the tongues amongst us; but that is nothing new to me.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. SELWYN.
SP.P: But it is very new in this house, and what we never ap∣prove. George, to be sure, sometimes thinking himself wiser than any of us, prefers giving his opinion to hear∣ing ours; however, we seldom spare him, for it is unpar∣donable, even in a rude unpolished school-boy, to behave in that manner, but in young ladies, it proves a want of delicacy and sentiment. Fie, Teresa! I thought you had too much gentleness to be guilty of such an error.
SP.STAGE: [Miss Selwyn appears to be quite distressed, but continues silent,]

SP.SPEAKER: Miss VERNON.
SP.P: We never passed a day in the convent without half a dozen quarrels amongst the boarders; by which mean I am so accustomed to them, that I could not live in quiet∣ness for the world. You look quite ashamed of it, cousin, why, I am not.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. VERNON.
SP.P: This is one of the blessed effects of the foreign educa∣tion you have had; and your speech convinces me, that you alone were to blame; poor Teresa could not avoid be∣ing a spectator; but her distressed appearance plainly speaks she took no other part in the contention.

SP.SPEAKER: Miss VERNON.
SP.P: I imagine, my cousin is to be supposed always in the right, because she was bred at home under your tuition, grandmamma, and according to your precepts. But con∣sider the change of fashions in the last sixty years, and how different young people are now to what they were formerly.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. VERNON.
SP.P: It is with great concern I observe the alteration you mention; but sixty years cannot make absurdity appear like reason, or pertness, like understanding.

SP.SPEAKER: Miss VERNON.
SP.P:
I suppose, if I was demure, simple, and silent, you would
call me modest, and well bred; but what use would it be to have accomplishments if I did not try to shew them?

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. VERNON.
SP.P: Do you then think, Cecilia, impertinent unmeaning remarks are proofs of knowledge? you take the method to convince us of the contrary: silence might hide your deficiency; there is no being mistaken when once you open your mouth.

SP.SPEAKER: Miss VERNON.
SP.P: It is a little hard, that I may not speak of the customs which prevail among people with whom I have passed almost half my life; but I suppose I am prevented, for fear I should convince others that I know more than my listeners.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. VERNON.
SP.P: Incorrigible girl! have you no affection? no feeling? no sense of duty?

SP.SPEAKER: Miss VERNON.
SP.P: You do not give me any opportunity of shewing my sentiments. It is hard to be received with frowns after so long an absence, and all occasioned by that young frip∣on my brother.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. SELWYN.
SP.P: My dear madam, let us wave all further argument. George, give your sister a reconciling kiss, and we will call another subject.
SP.STAGE: [Master Vernon just touches Miss Vernon's cheek, then speaks.

SP.SPEAKER: Master VERNON.
SP.P: Was that done gently enough to please you, madame Francis?

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. G. VERNON.
SP.P: Hsh! George, I must not allow you to take such lib∣erties with your sister, if you repeat it, I will instantly send you to . Did you, Teresa, invite the young ladies to tea this afternoon?

SP.SPEAKER: Miss SELWYN.
SP.P:
I wrote notes to them, madam, as you directed, request∣ing
their company to meet an old friend; they returned for answer that they should be happy to wait on me, and would come early, according to my desire.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. G. VERNON.
SP.P: I hope, my dears, you will not dispute before your visitors.

SP.SPEAKER: Master VERNON.
SP.P: I shall not begin first. But I am determined to go into the room to see how Cecilia behaves, and what french∣ified airs she puts on.

SP.SPEAKER: Miss VERNON.
SP.P: I do not think it worth while to argue with such a rude boy as you are. Pray, cousin, who are the young ladies we are to see this afternoon?

SP.SPEAKER: Miss SELWYN.
SP.P: Miss Ward, Miss Franklin, and Miss Thurot; the fa∣ther of Miss Thurot is a French refuge; the other two ladies, you no doubt recollect?

SP.SPEAKER: Miss VERNON.
SP.P: Come then, let us go into the drawing-room and pre∣pare for them.
[She runs out; Miss Selwyn curtefies to her friends, and follows her.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. VERNON.
SP.P: Come, my good Mrs. Selwyn, lead me to the couch in the little parlour, that I may take my afternoon's sleep.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. G. VERNON, alone.
SP.P:
With what difficulty have I smothered my grief and disappointment. Alas! Cecilia's temper is quite spoiled. O that I had followed her grandmother's advice, and ed∣ucated her with her cousin; but headstrong and opinion∣ated people generally suffer as I do. What steps can I take to undo what seven years seem to have fatally com∣pleted? had but her father's life been spared, he would have saved her from perversion, and me from the fatal in∣strument of being it. Why did I follow my own infatu∣ated opinion? Too prophetic mother, all your apprehen∣sions
are verified! I must go to my daughter, and try to compose my mind, it is at present greatly disturbed.

DIV3.HEAD: SCENE changes to the Drawing-Room.
[Miss Selwyn, Miss and Master Vernon.]

SP.SPEAKER: Miss SELWYN.
SP.P: I long to hear you play on the harpsichord, Cecilia; I shall hope to improve myself, by catching your graces.

SP.SPEAKER: Miss VERNON.
SP.P: I suppose you have an English master and English ?

SP.SPEAKER: Miss SELWYN.
SP.P: I play of all kinds; my master is still the same you began with, and is reckoned a remarkably good one.

SP.SPEAKER: Miss VERNON.
SP.P: He may be thought so here, but I was obliged to un∣learn all he taught me; my French master told me, I had been most execrably instructed.

SP.SPEAKER: Miss SELWYN.
SP.P: That he might say to answer some purpose of his own. Perhaps an English performer may not possess the spirit and brilliancy of a French one; but I have been told the latter are apt to neglect laying a solid foundation, which is the method our good masters always observe.

SP.SPEAKER: Miss VERNON.
SP.P: I really knw nothing about the matter; and I never give myself the trouble to think: Monsieur de Brun was a very polite man, and always praised me.
SP.STAGE: [Master Vernon looking out of the window.]

SP.SPEAKER: Master VERNON.
SP.P: Here come our visitors. Now, Cecilia, for some of your French airs and graces?

SP.SPEAKER: Miss VERNON.
SP.P: I wish I could transport you to the antipodes; you are the most impertinent boy I ever knew.
SP.STAGE: [Enter the three young ladies; Miss Selwyn advances to meet them with great politeness, and introduces them to Miss Vernon.]

SP.SPEAKER: Miss SELWYN.
SP.P: Miss Ward, Miss Franklin, Miss Thurot, need I name the lady to whom I am introducing you?

SP.SPEAKER: Miss VERNON.
SP.P: Oui, certainment; Am I not entierement grown out of their knowledge?

SP.SPEAKER: Miss WARD.
SP.P: Miss Vernon, I rejoice to see you.

SP.SPEAKER: M FRANKLIN.
SP.P: It is certainly your old playfellow! How glad I am you are returned home! [They advance and embrace her.]

SP.SPEAKER: Miss THUROT.
SP.P: Though I have not had the pleasure of seeing you be∣fore, yet I am a sharer with your other friends, Miss Vernon, in the happiness your return gives them, for I have heard you so frequently spoken of, that I longed to see you.

SP.SPEAKER: Miss VERNON.
SP.P: Je suis ravi a ce moment, which once more unites me a mes belles amies, among whom I am rejoiced to reck∣on you [addressing Miss Thurot.]

SP.SPEAKER: Miss WARD.
SP.P: How happy you must be to come home! La, my dear, was not a convent a detestible place? from what I have read and heard of them, I would not go to one for the world.

SP.SPEAKER: Miss VERNON.
SP.P: I cannot pretend to say it was bien charmant; but I shall now reap the advantage by having been educated in a superior style.

SP.SPEAKER: Miss FRANKLIN.
SP.P: I doubt not your accomplishments, Miss Vernon. But you must be very clever indeed to exceed our dear Teresa who is reckoned a perfect prodigy.

SP.SPEAKER: Miss SELWYN. [blushing.]
SP.P: Pray do not bestow such undeserved praises on me; I do not wish to vie with any one.

SP.SPEAKER: Miss WARD.
SP.P: Well, you are very clever to be sure, at least we are told so; but I think Miss Vernon will be more to my taste, she seems so lively.

SP.SPEAKER: Miss VERNON.
SP.P: Me? je suis toujours gaie. I have overturned the heads of the whole family in the short time since my return.

SP.SPEAKER: Master VERNON.
SP.P: It is time then you settled your own, for if you do not take care it will all drop off presently.

SP.SPEAKER: Miss VERNON.
SP.P: I wish, sir, you were gone to school.

SP.SPEAKER: Master VERNON.
SP.P: I dare say you do; and I shall be very ready to go, that I may entertain my school-fellows with an imitation of some of your grimmaces.

SP.SPEAKER: Miss VERNON.
SP.P: I do not mind you, that is one comfort. What shall we do to divert ourselves?

SP.SPEAKER: Miss THUROT.
SP.P: Any thing that is agreeable to these young ladies will be so to me. But I am so fond of music, that I should prefer that entertainment to any other.

SP.SPEAKER: Miss SELWYN.
SP.P: My cousin, I hope, will not refuse to begin.

SP.SPEAKER: Miss VERNON.
SP.P: I would rather hear somebody else first. That mad boy has agitated me I cannot sing yet.

SP.SPEAKER: Miss SELWYN.
SP.P: Then I will set the example in hope of having it fol∣lowed, and that my playing may not appear to the disad∣vantage it must do after hearing a better performer.

[Miss Selwyn plays and sings, during which time Miss Thurot and Miss Franklin, stand by her listening. Miss Vernon and Miss Ward whisper and laugh. Master Vernon eyes them very archly; when it is over, Miss Selwyn rises.

SP.SPEAKER: Miss THUROT.
SP.P:
You play enchantingly, Miss Selwyn, I wish I could
perform as well, my papa would be delighted to hear you; he is amazingly lond of music, and very anxious for me to excel in it.

SP.SPEAKER: Miss VERNON.
SP.P: Indeed, cousin, you are a great proficient, and sing a merveille!
SP.STAGE: [Master Vernon bursts into a loud laugh.]

SP.SPEAKER: Master VERNON.
SP.P: Pray how much did you hear of it? for you have been louder than the music.

SP.SPEAKER: Miss WARD.
SP.P: Come, Miss Vernon, you must absolutely play now. I am dying to hear you.

SP.SPEAKER: Miss VERNON [rises with great affectation.]
SP.P: I will with pleasure oblige you. [Takes a French sang out of her pocket; then seats herself, and begins play∣ing, during which she throws herself into attitudes like foreigners. Soon after she begins, Master Vernon, who has observed her sometime, goes out, then returns with a ooking glass, which he places suddenly before her.]

SP.SPEAKER: Miss VERNON.
SP.P: What is that for, sir?

SP.SPEAKER: Master VERNON.
SP.P: To shew you what a monkey is like. Why, I never saw any thing else like you.

SP.SPEAKER: Miss VERNON.
SP.P: This is too much to submit to, making me break off in the finest part of the song, and disappointing the young ladies.

SP.SPEAKER: Master VERNON.
SP.P: Do not make yourself uneasy about that, I will enter∣tain the ladies quite in your stile. [He imitates her action and manner of singing.]

SP.SPEAKER: Miss VERNON, [bursts into tears.]
SP.P: I cannot submit to such cruel usage. Why, if you must play ridiculous tricks, did you not chuse Teresa instead of me to make your subject?

SP.SPEAKER: Master VERNON.
SP.P: Because she did nothing ridiculous. Why, there was not one of your cheres amies, that did not laugh at you.

SP.SPEAKER: Miss VERNON.
SP.P: Insufferable insolence! I will complain to my mamma if you persist in abusing me.

SP.SPEAKER: Miss SELWYN.
SP.P: Pray George, forbear, indeed you are wrong to distress your sister.

SP.SPEAKER: Miss VERNON.
SP.P: It is impossible I should play, or do any thing else well whilst he is ridiculing me.

SP.SPEAKER: Master VERNON.
SP.P: It is only owing to my ignorance. Consider I never saw a frenchified belle before. Miss Thurot was born in France, why does not she behave like you if it is the fashion of that nation?

SP.SPEAKER: Miss THUROT.
SP.P: No, sir, I was born and educated in England, my pa∣rents were French.

SP.SPEAKER: Master VERNON.
SP.P: Well then if it was right to squeeze about like my sister, to be sure your papa and mamma would have taught you to do it.

SP.SPEAKER: Miss WARD.
SP.P: Pray, Master Vernon, do not say any more, you quite spoil our amusement. Come, let one of us play while the rest dance.

SP.SPEAKER: Miss VERNON.
SP.P: De tout mon coeur. I am now again ready for any thing lively.

SP.SPEAKER: Master VERNON.
SP.P: I hope I shall have the honor of dancing with every lady but my sister. If she dances as she plays, I can never hope to possess perfection enough for her partner.

SP.SPEAKER: Miss SELWYN.
SP.P: Who will begin?—Accept me as a fidler. [She fits down to the harpsichord and plays a minuet.]
[Master Vernon takes out Miss Ward and Miss Franklin, and dances alternately with them.]

SP.SPEAKER: Master VERNON.
SP.P: I am quite tired.—Come let the French ladies dance together.

SP.SPEAKER: Miss THUROT.
SP.P: If Miss Vernon will accept an indifferent partner, I am at her service.

[Whilst they are settling themselves, George slyly pins a cracker on the back of his sister's gown; just as she is do∣ing the pas grave, at giving her second hand, he contrives, by means of a lighted paper, to set fire to it, and it goes off with a great bounce; she falls down in a fright, and all the rest run about screaming; he stands and laughs most vio∣lently.]

SP.SPEAKER: Miss SELWYN.
SP.P: Indeed, cousin George, you carry your jokes to a length infinitely beyond prudence; what have you done? my dear Cecilia suffer me to assist you in rising, I hope you are not hurt.

SP.SPEAKER: Miss VERNON.
SP.P: There is my grandmamma alarmed I dare say. What account, sir, will you give of yourself to her?

SP.SPEAKER: Master VERNON.
SP.P: I shall not trouble myself to give her any. I never heard a cracker go off so well in my life. [Laughs and holds his sides.]

DIV3.STAGE: [Enter Sally.]

SP.SPEAKER: SALLY.
SP.P: What is the matter in this room, ladies? my lady is excessively alarmed, and thinks some accident has hap∣pened.

SP.SPEAKER: Miss SELWYN.
SP.P: No person is hurt, Sally. The noise was owing to one of George's frolicks. Pray hasten to relieve my grandmamma's fears.

SP.SPEAKER: Miss VERNON.
SP.P: I wonder. Teresa, you, who are so very attentive to your old adviser, do not go and give her an account of every thing that is past.

SP.SPEAKER: Miss SELWYN.
SP.P: If any pleasant circumstance occurred, I should cer∣tainly put myself forward to relate it; but in the present ease, silence is best. To speak truth would pain her; and to utter falshood, is meanness.

SP.SPEAKER: Miss WARD.
SP.P: Well, I see no harm in deceiving an old woman. I am sure my grandmamma does not hear above one true word in ten from me; indeed, I do not trouble myself to talk much to her; for I hate to satisfy her tiresome quest∣ions.

SP.SPEAKER: Miss THUROT.
SP.P: I am surprised to hear you say so, for I think she and Mrs. Vernon are the most pleasing old ladies I ever saw, they always have such a benignant smile, and are so condesending to young people.

SP.SPEAKER: Miss VERNON.
SP.P: The smiles of old women are, in my eyes, only sneers. But it is the fashion to look upon our old ladies as oracles, so we must submit to the hearing them; but further than this, I cannot go.

SP.SPEAKER: Miss SELWYN.
SP.P: Well, I own, there is something so mild and good in my grandmamma's appearance, that when I am with her, I cannot help thinking she is a being superior to the gene∣rality of the world.

SP.SPEAKER: Miss FRANKLIN.
SP.P: And so she is. I am sure I hear her praised wherever I go; they say she is both wise and good.

SP.SPEAKER: Miss THUROT.
SP.P: I declare, I am never so happy as when permitted to pass a few hours with her, and always return home with some new sentiments, collected from her conversation, that make me wiser and better.

SP.SPEAKER: Master VERNON.
SP.P: Well, ladies, I think you are rather on a dry subject. Have you no new plays?

SP.SPEAKER: Miss VERNON.
SP.P: I bar every thing like play in your company. You have almost killed me with your evil tricks.

SP.SPEAKER: Master VERNON.
SP.P: So much the better; then you will never dance and sing again.

SP.SPEAKER: Miss SELWYN.
SP.P: Pray, George, recollect yourself; indeed, you for∣get that you ought to protect your sister from insolence, not make her the subject of it.

SP.SPEAKER: Master VERNON.
SP.P: Well then, peace for ever, I proclaim it. Come, sister▪ shake hands. I should not have thought of doing what I have done, but to please and entertain you, because you boasted of having such uncommon spirits.

SP.SPEAKER: Miss VERNON.
SP.P: And so I have, George, if I might be permitted to in∣dulge them. I have not been in the garden yet since my return. and long to see the improvements.

SP.SPEAKER: Miss SELWYN.
SP.P: We had better then go immediately, or the evening will close and prevent us; on our return tea will be ready▪

SP.SPEAKER: Master VERNON.
SP.P: I shall go and fly my kite then during your walk, for would by no means interrupt your agreeable conversation.

SP.SPEAKER: Miss WARD.
SP.P: Do as you please, sir; we are not ambitious of you company.

SP.SPEAKER: Miss VERNON.
SP.P: Pray do not begin with him, he seems inclined to quiet, and let us keep him so.

SP.SPEAKER: Master VERNON.
SP.P: Your servant, ladies.

SP.SPEAKER: Miss FRANKLIN.
SP.P: Here are our calashes. I am ready.

SP.SPEAKER: Miss THUROT.
SP.P: So are we.

SP.SPEAKER: Miss VERNON.
SP.P: We can take ours as we go through the hall.
SP.STAGE: [As they are going out, enter Sally.]

SP.SPEAKER: SALLY.
SP.P: My lady desires to see Miss Selwyn, and one of the other young ladies.

SP.SPEAKER: Miss VERNON.
SP.P: Not me, I dare say.

SP.SPEAKER: SALLY.
SP.P: No Miss, one of the visitors.

SP.SPEAKER: Miss FRANKLIN.
SP.P: May I be indulged with the honor of accompanying you, Teresa?

SP.SPEAKER: Miss THUROT.
SP.P: A little French quickness would have stood my friend now, for you are beforehand with me Amelia.

SP.SPEAKER: Miss WARD.
SP.P: Then you had better both go. Miss Vernon and I are ready to excuse you.

SP.SPEAKER: Miss VERNON.
SP.P: Allons done!—Come let us hasten, or it will be dark.

SP.SPEAKER: Miss THUROT.
SP.P: May I take the liberty of going with you to your grandmamma's apartment, Teresa?

SP.SPEAKER: Miss SELWYN.
SP.P: Undoubtedly; and you will make her very happy in your company.

SP.SPEAKER: Miss THUROT.
SP.P: Thus kindly encouraged, I cannot resist the opportu∣nity of enjoying so great a pleasure.

DIV3.HEAD: SCENE, the Drawing-Room. The tea things set.
[Mrs. G. Vernon and Mrs. Selwyn.]

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. SELWYN.
SP.P: I HAVE sent the dear girls in quest of their compan∣ions, and when they return will make the .

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. VERNON.
SP.P: I am in no hurry. You are not well, daughter, I fear.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. G. VERNON.
SP.P: My mind, dear madam, is greatly disturbed. [She bursts into tears.] The consequence of my strange infa∣tuation have, I fear, quite changed the once gentle mind of my poor Cecilia.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. VERNON.
SP.P: If you are convinced it wants correcting my fears abate; she is young, and may yet be taught to overcome the pre∣judices of education, difficult as I fear the task may prove; but I own, I apprehended you would be as blind to her errors as you were to her interest, when you determined on giving her a foreign education.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. G. VERNON.
SP.P: You know not, my dear mother, the misery that I now experience, for having obstinately persevered in an opin∣ion so fatal to my child. O! that I alone suffered! un∣happy girl! my fatal impropriety has perverted her heart, and deprived her of those finer feelings, which are the greatest ornaments of the female mind.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. SELWYN.
SP.P: Comfort yourself dear Louisa, your daughter is not old in error; the very acquisitions she so much plumes herself upon, will only turn to her mortification. Intro∣duce her among amiable people; their example will shew her the absurdity of her own conceit, and teach her how trifling outward accomplishments are, when unaccompa∣nied by diffidence and modesty.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. VERNON.
SP.P: Nor will it be amiss to let her sometimes mix with young people as improperly educated as herself. The contrast will be striking, and more convincing than pre∣cept; she must be led by gentleness, by attentively watch∣ing every turn of her mind, we may imperceptibly im∣plant that solid virtue we wish to cultivate.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. G. VERNON.
SP.P: I ought not to despair I have such kind and able assistants; but I do not deserve, after my miserable mis∣management, the happiness of seeing my daughter like her cousin.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. VERNON.
SP.P: Subject as we all are to errors, it is our duty to excuse them. Parents who love their children, certainly wish to fix on the properest mode of education, and such as they think will lead them to the good they wish them to gain. But here the parent's mind betrays the child, and the worldly minded cannot expect such blessed effects as generally reward those who have a view to higher con∣siderations.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. G. VERNON.
SP.P: But I, madam, had better advisers, and might have es∣caped the rock so plainly pointed out to me.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. VERNON.
SP.P: You were young, and perhaps thought an old woman's advice the effect of age and spleen; but tha past. Let us now endeavour to overcome what we could not prevent. You, Louisa, must be the great actor: your daughter will not regard the monitions of her and me, unless they are supported you. The first thing, therefore, you have to determine on, is steadiness; upon no account be led to smile, or encourage any of her live∣ly sallies, (as she terms them,) which at best are only pe∣ness and sppancy.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. SELWYN.
SP.P:
My sister, who is so different herself, will not, I think, allow in Cecilia such wretched meanness, by some called, wit, which consists in ridiculing the worthy; some, be∣cause they are old; others, because they are grave; and
others, because they are ugly; to such persons, an old face, a large nose, a wide mouth, little eyes, &c. will fur∣nish subjects for mirth during a whole afternoon, to those who do not consider the wickedness of remarks which re∣flect on the divine hand that formed persons with these imperfections, not on the unfortunate possessors of them.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. G. VERNON.
SP.P: Indeed, Charlotte, I detest such kind of conversation as much as you can do; for it is totally inconsistent with that commendable sensibility which ought to make a part of the female character. Persons who have a turn to this kind of ridicule, must either be insensibly thoughtless or else cruel and malicious.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. VERNON.
SP.P: Perless, in my opinion, is detestable. How often have I seen low ridicule put the worthy and the diffident out of countenance, while many stood smiling round, en∣joying the jest, and the confusion it produced.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. G. VERNON.
SP.P: Upon those occasions frequently have I prayed, that my children might escape such unworthy sentiments; and now, by my mode of education, they seem to be the cha∣racteristic of them both.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. SELWYN.
SP.P: I am not alarmed on George's account; he has a great deal of good sense under the roughness of a school-boy; and I think, the scene that passed this afternoon, which Miss Franklin really described in a very diverting manner, will be a mean of shewing Cecilia, the absurdity of her conduct.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. VERNON.
SP.P: Certainly; while he ridiculed his sister's folly, he shewed a distinguishing mind, for he did not attempt ri∣diculing any of the other young ladies.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. G. VERNON.
SP.P: But surely he ought not to be encouraged in treating Cecilia with contempt, and making her the subject of mirth to himself and friends.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. SELWYN.
SP.P: Undoubtedly not; we must endeavour to convince him of this impropriety and teach him to correct it; but yet, his behaviour may be made a useful lesson to his sister.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. G. VERNON.
SP.P: I wish she may be prevailed on to receive it as such.—But alas! she seems very little disposed to avail herself of any mode of instruction.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. SELWYN.
SP.P: Let us hope the best my dear sister. The follies we have this day observed in Cecilia, shew a perverted under∣standing, it must be owned, but do not prove that she has a ad heart. I wish much to know whether she has es∣caped perversion in a very material point—I mean Reli∣gion.—The danger in this respect, has all along appeared to me so great, that I could never think of it without hor∣ror.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. VERNON.
SP.P: It is a subject we must at least for a time avoid talking upon to her, though of infinitely the greatest consequence; our own attention will soon enable us to make every re∣quisue observation, and instruct us in the best methods to pursue.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. G. VERNON.
SP.P: I shudder to reflect on what a precipice my belov∣ed Cecilia stands. O, that my prayers may avail to avert this most poignant misfortune! I must enter upon the subject as soon as possible, for I am all anxiety to know what my child is.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. SELWYN.
SP.P: Keep up your spirits, however my dear sister; you must have all your thoughts about you, and endeavour to take the lead in every conversation at which Cecilia is present.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. G. VERNON.
SP.P:
I will certainly follow your advice, and study to re∣trieve my past errors. Wonderful! that I should per∣sist for seven years in one which deprived me of my greatest joy and comfort; for never mother loved a child more than I do my Cecilia; and, but for what I thought her advantage, she should never have been out of my sight. Often have I envied you, sister, in having Terea
with you, and should certainly have sent for my daughter, but that a false shame restrained me from it; though I always dreaded, as much as longed, for her teturn.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. VERNON.
SP.P: I think, daughter, the expence of education abroad is nearly as much as at home; and if so, what reason can there be for banishing a child so many years?

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. G. VERNON.
SP.P: Indeed, madam, Cecilia's education has cost me even more than it would have done in England. The first year the demands for it were moderate, and according to the agreement I made; but they have increased since more that I wish to own; for this confession only adds to the inexcufeableness of my conduct. The superior of the convent, solemnly engaged to leave her free in res∣pect to religion; but disappointed as I am in other res∣pects, I can have little hopes that her mind remains un∣tainted in this particular.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. SELWYN [moves to the tea table.]
SP.P: I hear the voices of the young people, and will there∣fore prepare for them.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. VERNON.
SP.P: Do, my dear, perhaps during tea we may draw from Cecilia opinions that will instruct us for our future pro∣ceedings.

DIV3.STAGE: [Enter Miss Selwyn, Miss Franklin, and Miss Thurot.]

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. SELWYN.
SP.P: Are you come alone, ladies?

SP.SPEAKER: Miss SELWYN.
SP.P: We could not find my cousin and Miss Ward; but as we entered the house heard their voices and George's ve∣ry loud by the filbert hedge.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. VERNON.
SP.P: They are coming. I hear a strange noise.
SP.STAGE: [Enter Master Vernon with a handful of false hair in one hand, dragging in his sister with the other, her cap off, her curls unpinned, and hanging about her ears, and she in tears, Miss Ward follows taking her part.]
SP.P: Master Vernon [laughing, and holding up the false hair.

SP.SPEAKER: Master VERNON.
SP.P: Look here! I have found her out! I knew, all that immense head could not belong to one person.

SP.SPEAKER: Miss VERNON.
SP.P: Am I not to find protection any where? rescue me, I beseech you, dear mamma, from this cruel boy.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. G. VERNON [separates them.]
SP.P: For shame, George, is this the treatment due from a brother to a sister? you who should protect her from the insolence of others, instead of setting such an exam∣ple. What would your wortly father say, if he could look out of his grave, and see his representative acting so differently from what he himself would do?

SP.SPEAKER: Master VERNON.
SP.P: I did not mean to hurt her, but she would not own her having false hair, so I was determined to find it out, and I discovered her nicely.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. VERNON.
SP.P: It is in vain to reason with you, sir; but you shall go to school to-morrow, and never come home till you have learnt to behave with more propriety. Your sister's foi∣bles, however great, ought not to be subjects for ridicule, but pity, to her nearest relations.

SP.SPEAKER: Master VERNON.
SP.P: Well, I am sure, she spares none of her relations; for they all have their turn to be laughed at.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. VERNON.
SP.P: I am sorry to hear she is capable of so much giddiness. If she did set you the example, George, she has suffered sufficiently for it and I am concerned; to find that as you had discernment enough to distinguish how unamiable it was in her, you had not sufficient prudence to prevent your falling into the error. [During this conversa∣tion, the young ladies adjust Miss Vernon's dress.]

SP.SPEAKER: Miss VERNON.
SP.P: I am sure my brother has tormented me ever since I entered this house. I think it is very hard I cannot find peace at home.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. SELWYN.
SP.P: Indeed it is, my poor Cecilia; nor can I think you could deserve such treatment by any expressions of your own.

SP.SPEAKER: Miss VERNON, [looks ashamed.]
SP.P: Whatever I have said, aunt, was only in jest.

SP.SPEAKER: Master VERNON.
SP.P: Well it was the same with me. I meant no harm, on∣ly a little diversion.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. VERNON.
SP.P: You have both been extremely to blame; and your punishment, Cecilia, though inflicted by a wrong person, is such as may shew you the impropriety of that low mean opinion, which leads you, when in the ridiculing vein, to spare neither friend nor relation.

SP.SPEAKER: Miss VERNON.
SP.P: It is very hard, mamma, that I must not speak a word, but my brother will repeat it to my disadvantage.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. G. VERNON.
SP.P: Say nothing improper, and you need not fear a repe∣tition of it. Do by others as you would have them do by you, and you will no longer be guilty of a fault that must tender your company unpleasant to every one.

SP.SPEAKER: Miss VERNON.
SP.P: La! mamma, one cannot be expected to think at my age as you do. I often speak without any meaning at all.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. VERNON.
SP.P: And by that mean wound where you should be kind. The tricks your brother has played you he did unthinking∣ly; yet you do not accept that excuse from him as a com∣pensation.

SP.SPEAKER: Miss VERNON.
SP.P: No, certainly, because he hurt me, and made me ap∣pear absurd, before company.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. VERNON.
SP.P: Yet you can with pleasure, by flippancy, put the modest out of countenance, merely because they are without the same talents to retort.

SP.SPEAKER: Miss VERNON.
SP.P: I never thought about it before, nor was I ever correc∣ted upon the subject, but was always encouraged by my companions to make them laugh.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. VERNON.
SP.P: You have more excuse than any of these young ladies could have for the same sault, because you have been de∣prived of good advisers; but I hope to convince you, how very disagreeable such kind of low wit must render you.
[Miss Ward appears confused.]

SP.SPEAKER: Miss VERNON.
SP.P: But you will allow grandmamma, that the natural fiveliness of young people may sometimes lead them to say and do things they ought not.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. VERNON.
SP.P: I make every allowance for the inexperience and vola∣tility of youth; but when a fault proceeds from an un∣feeling heart, it is, in my eyes, unpardonable; and I have no idea that a person of a good disposition can, at any age, take pleasure in putting another out of countenance, merely for thinking they have said a good thing. As one of my favorite author's says,Young's Universal Passion,

L.HI: "Who for the poor renown of being smart,
"Would leave a sting within another's heart?"

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. SELWYN.
SP.P: George, give the ladies their tea; you shall wait upon us this afternoon.

SP.SPEAKER: Master VERNON.
SP.P: I am very happy to be employed; and what is more, I am sorry for my behaviour to my sister, and will never act so again to any one. I had no design to be ill-natured, though it appeared that I had. [He goes to her, and takes her hand very affectionately.] Come Cecilia, you must forgive me.

SP.SPEAKER: Miss VERNON.
SP.P: Most cordially, George, and I thank you for your ex∣cuses. I am quite ashamed of my own conduct, which drew upon me your censure.

SP.SPEAKER: Master VERNON.
SP.P: Indeed, Cecilia, without a jest, you do not appear half so well as these other young ladles. I should not find fault with you if you were like them.

SP.SPEAKER: Miss VERNON.
SP.P: Well, sir, you need not begin again.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. G. VERNON, [interrupting her.]
SP.P: Now I must take my son's part. He has indeed given you most excellent advice. Your spirits appear assumed and not natural. Some young people are livelier than others; and, when it is the bent of their dispositions, their liveliness is very pleasing; but you Cecilia, when a child were always grave; your present mode of conduct does not, therefore, sit easy upon you.

SP.SPEAKER: Miss VERNON. [after a pause.]
SP.P: My dear mamma, I will confess my inward mind to you. I was so unhappy in the convent, that had I not assumed this frivolous manner of behaviour I should have fretted myself to death. You were too distant to hear my complaints. I was not permitted to write to you. Ha∣bit familiarised nonsense; and I thought it right on my return to appear as I had done abroad, that I might be un∣like every one bred in England. I shall endeavour to resume my natural temper, though your instruction will be necessary to remind me when I forget myself.
Mrs. G. Vernon [looks delighted, and takes her hand.]

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. G. VERNON.
SP.P: With pleasure I accept the office you appoint, and will be your monitor on all necessary occasions.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. VERNON.
SP.P: Come, and let me embrace my beloved child, the dear offspring of an excellent son. Your last speech has given me a joy I little expected to feel from your late appearance. [They embrace and shed tears.]

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. SELWYN.
SP.P: I too must share these caresses, and tell my dear Cecilia, I love her with a mother's fondness.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. G. VERNON.
SP.P: Had you been her mother she would not have been thrown on such rocks as I placed in her way; but she is rescued from them, for which I return my unfeigned thanks where due.

SP.SPEAKER: Miss SELWYN.
SP.P: I hope my dear consin, you will now love me as well as ever, and let us henceforth be friends and sisters.

SP.SPEAKER: Miss VRENON.
SP.P: That I will, my dear Teresa, and with joy accept your kind invitation; though I own, with blushes, the hope of out-doing you, made me purchase that false hair which produced my shame, and now my happiness.

SP.SPEAKER: Miss WARD.
SP.P: Do not blame yourself, or your education too dear Miss Vernon, since you are kindly pardoned. I have always practised the same flippancy; but from this moment will endeavour to divest myself of it, and will never treat my grandmamma improperly again.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. SELWYN.
SP.P: An excellent resolution my dear, and I doubt not your keeping it. We wil have the tea equipage removed, and then proceed to something more like amusen than the past conversation has been. [The bell is rung, a footman enters, and goes out with the tea things.

SP.SPEAKER: Miss FRANKLI.
SP.P: I cannot wish for any entertainment that deprives us of the instruction which the conversation of the present company, always conveys, in which I learn sentiments I hope never to forget.

SP.SPEAKER: Miss THUROT.
SP.P: I always lament losing a moment which might be so well spent.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. VERNON.
SP.P: You are very polite young ladies, with such a disposi∣tion your society will be desirable to people of all ages. But there is time for all things. Youth is the season for gaiety; enjoy it properly, only act with discretion; then you may look forward to a peaceable old age, un∣embittered by regret for mispent time.

SP.SPEAKER: Miss THUROT.
SP.P: Pray, Miss Vernon, did you go to mss?

SP.SPEAKER: Miss VERNON.
SP.P: Not constantly; but I sometimes went, and was for∣ced to attend all hours of devotion in the convent, ex∣cept in the night, those I was excused from.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. G. VERNON, [in an agitation.]
SP.P: And how did you like it?

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. G. VERNON, [in an agitation.]
SP.P: how did you like it?

SP.SPEAKER: Miss VERNON.
SP.P: I was pleased with the solemnity of their worship; and still I must confess, my dear mamma, that I rather feel a bias towards a religion which, notwithstanding the promises that were made to you to the contrary, those who had the care of my education took so much pains to inculcate; and had it not been for the urgent desire I felt o return to England, I certainly should have profes∣sed myself a Roman Catholic; but I knew I should by this mean cut myself off from my family and dearest con∣nections, therefore, resolved to resist all importunities; and the levity of conduct which I assumed, (though high∣ly blameable) was thus far serviceable to me, that it selt me little time to attend to any serious subject; for, except during the time of divine service, and whilst I was re∣iving grave lectures, I seldom thought on religion at all.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. G. VERNON.
SP.P: What a fortunate escape have you had. Oh, how my heart reproaches me for the danger I have exposed you to!

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. VERNON.
SP.P: Do not, my dear daughter, afflict yourself too much for an error, which, I trust, is not irreparable. I hope, from the comparison which Cecilia, now she is of an age to distinguish, will be able to make between our rational ser∣vice and the unmeaning pageantry of the Romish Church, she will easily incline to give preference to the former; and that we shall be able to eradicate the false prejudices she has unhappily imbibed.

SP.SPEAKER: Miss VERNON.
SP.P: Indeed, my dear grandmamma, I will with pleasure attend to the instructions of you and the rest of my good friends.—I am very ignorant, but I yield myself to your guidance.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. VERNON.
SP.P: Your friends will have pleasure in the task; and I am thankful that you have but little more than ignorance to overcome. How much worse might it not have been?

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. G. VERNON.
SP.P:
In the of my bitter regret, a happy prospect persents
itself before me. Your advice, dear mother shall in future have its due influence with me, and, I hope wih mine; and may Heaven great you length of days for your comfort!

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. VERNON.
SP.P: Whilst my life is spared, I wish to make is as useful as possible. But, whenever I go, there is no fear but your good sense, which enables you to perceive your late error, will keep you in the path you should tread in, as much for your own sake, as for these dear children's whose guide you must be.

SP.SPEAKER: Master VERNON.
SP.P: I do not know what ails me, but I am ready to ry; and am sorry for having been at times so pert to all my relations.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. SELWYN.
SP.P: Well said, my dear boy, a fault handsomely acknow∣ledged claims forgiveness, and I doubt not, your prov∣ing as great a comfort to us all as our beloved Cecilia.

SP.SPEAKER: Master VERNON.
SP.P: Thank you aunt, for your good opinion. Desire mamma to let me have two or three holidays, and I will not for a long time intrude on her goodness.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. G. VERNON.
SP.P: Upon that condition I grant your request; I like to indulge you, George, but must keep you more strictly to your learning, for I fear coming home so often has in∣terfered with your Greek and Latin.

SP.SPEAKER: Master VERNON.
SP.P: Not very much, mamma. But, indeed, I will take more pains inuture.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. SELWYN.
SP.P: By way of composing our spirits, what say you to a few minutes? our footman plays a decent fiddle; he is in the hall.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. G. VERNON.
SP.P: I am obliged to you for the proposal, sister, and hope my dear mother will give the young people an applauding smile.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. VERNON.
SP.P: With pleasure. Only to avoid catching cold I will sit in my little parlour and look through the glass door at them.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. SELWYN.
SP.P:
Go then, my dears, and see that every thing is in readiness,
and desire John to rosin his bow, for I think you will exercise it. [The young people all go out.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. G. VERNON.
SP.P: What an undeservedly happy woman am I! and how has this blest hour relieved my heart from agony too great to be long endured!

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. VERNON.
SP.P: Your future attention to your children's welfare will, I hope, enfure you a continuance of your present happy prospects, and bless us in their rising virtues.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. SELWYN.
SP.P: We ought with heart-felt thankfulness to acknowledge, that all our present comfort arises from the over-ruling hand of Providence; which alone preserved our dear child from absolute perversion. But let not any parent be encouraged from hence to expose theirs to the same temptation, as they cannot know what the event may be.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. VERNON.
SP.P: Though this dear child had not been entirely neglected in her infancy from an idea of her being too young to receive religious instructions, yet what might have become of her when transported into a foreign land, before any good principle iad taken root in her mind?

DIV3.STAGE: [Enter a Footman.]

SP.SPEAKER: FOOTMAN.
SP.P: Every thing is ready madam, and the ladies beg me tell you they are impatient to begin.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. G. VERNON.
SP.P: We will attend them immediately. [Footman goes out.] Come, dear mother and sister, let me lead you to a scene of innocent festivity.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. VERNON.
SP.P: With inexpressible delight do I accompany you, and am thankful that I have lived to see this day, in which my family are again collected, and my fears for one dear branch of it happily removed.
